responses.content: We see so much headroom, given our bet on AI. Going to our most important product of all, Search, when you see the launch of BERT, which was a significant improvement, and we are following that up with MUM, which is another extraordinary advance. So the rate information is growing – pretty rapidly, and so constantly developing better models to improve our search quality ranking, etc., is one of the most important ways we invest. Beyond that, all the work we are doing into making sure computers can understand in a multimodal way, be it images, audio, text, video, and then bringing it up across our products is an important approach.

We see AI and ML as broader, deeper investments that we are driving and using across our product portfolio. The recent launch of Tensor and Pixel 6 is a great example. We are willing to go as deep in the stack as needed, with silicon both on the cloud side with our Tensor Processing Units and on the client side with Google Tensor. We are thinking through compute, networking, building data centers, making sure they are clean and carbon-free, and investing in advanced models and algorithms. Additionally, we are looking into areas like quantum computing.

In augmented reality, we have deeply focused on long-term computing advancements. We are investing in AR through products like Google Lens and ensuring Search works well in a multimodal and VR/AR world. We are investing in both our Hardware teams and platform teams to push computing forward and guide our ecosystem with an AI-first approach.

YouTube is unique as a video-native, video-first product. We have focused on content responsibility, supporting creators, and providing a great platform for advertisers. We are investing in features like Shorts and shopping capabilities to enhance user and advertiser experiences. Connected TV is the fastest-growing consumer surface, and we have over 120 million people watching YouTube on TVs monthly in the U.S. We are investing in integrating YouTube with platforms like Android TV, Google TV, and YouTube TV to enhance consumer adoption of Connected TVs.

philipp_schindler.role: Senior Vice President and Chief Business Officer

responses.content: We want to ensure that when people come to Google, they can find the best products and prices from the widest range of merchants. Under Bill’s leadership, we removed financial barriers by making listings free and removing commission fees. Combining free listings with Shopping Ads led to a 50% lift in clicks for merchants using both. In 2021, we focused on removing integration barriers through partnerships with Shopify, Square, BigCommerce, GoDaddy, WooCommerce, etc., making it easier for businesses to get started with Search, Shopping, Image Search, and YouTube.

Our direct response business on YouTube has seen exceptional growth. We launched shoppable capabilities, allowing viewers to make purchases directly from creators. Merchants can bring their product feeds into video campaigns, and we’re expanding these features. YouTube helps advertisers reach audiences they can’t find elsewhere, with over 2 billion monthly active users and a billion-plus hours of video watched daily. We’re investing in AR for in-store experiences online and enhancing features like Shopping Graph and Lens to open new product experiences.

We have a long-term growth opportunity in commerce. By removing financial and integration barriers, we have enabled more retailers to advertise effectively. We continue to simplify the user and merchant experience, provide measurement tools, and use AR to enhance shopping experiences. Initiatives like the Shopping Graph and Shopping with Lens are examples of how we’re innovating to support retailers and drive eCommerce growth.

We are committed to privacy-preserving technologies like the Privacy Sandbox to replace third-party cookies. We are collaborating with the ads community to develop open standard mechanisms that sustain a healthy, ad-supported web.

ruth_porat.role: Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

responses.content: We are continuing to invest meaningfully in Google Cloud, recognizing the opportunity. This includes expanding our global footprint, increasing compute capacity, and enhancing our product offerings. Recent additions like the second Cloud region in India reflect our ongoing commitment. We are focusing on industry-specific value propositions and maintaining a high level of investment in headcount, sales, and marketing.

Our approach to investing and capital allocation remains focused on supporting long-term growth with financially sustainable businesses. We are investing in operational excellence, technical infrastructure, and improving productivity. Despite some costs being less variable in the short term, such as depreciation and data center operations, we are increasing our investment pace in both Google Services and Google Cloud.

Advertising revenue growth is strong, reflecting broad-based strength across regions and verticals. We are focusing on operational excellence to drive long-term performance. Some margin improvements come from reduced costs like depreciation and lower impact from expenses like travel and marketing due to COVID-19.

We value bringing people together in the office and are adopting a hybrid work model. We are growing our headcount and investing in office facilities globally, with a focus on building out campuses to support our evolving work environment.

responses.topic: Impact of iOS Changes and Supply Chain
responses.content: The Apple iOS 14 changes had a modest impact on YouTube revenues, primarily in direct response. We are investing in privacy-preserving technologies to mitigate these impacts. Regarding supply and labor shortages, we saw some impact in the auto vertical, but it has been offset by increased demand in related areas like parts, accessories, and maintenance.

questions: First one for Sundar, big picture. Coming back to how you started the call, when you look out over the next three to five years, what do you see as some of the big investments that Google needs to make to marry your ambitions on AI and machine learning against aligning Google’s broader product and services against the rising digitalization of the global economy. Would love to have that as a framing over the next three to five years.

And then maybe -- I’m not sure if it’s directed better at Philipp or Ruth, but on a shorter-duration basis, there seemed to be an element of headwinds and tailwinds in the broader macro economy. Can you talk a little bit about the business elements of Google’s products and what elements of reopening dynamic you’re seeing on a sector basis versus potential headwinds as we move into Q4 next year from things like supply chain shortages or labor shortages or things like that.

You have made notable strides in the retail search category over the past 12 to 18 months, and there seems to be more to come. Can you talk to us about which other Search verticals – where you are most excited to innovate and invest around the next – within the next year or two?
And how do you think about the sustainability here, specifically in Search and the product pipeline from here?

And then, secondly, on Cloud, really saw a nice margin improvement there. How do you feel about where you are on the infrastructure side and ability to really continue to show kind of that improvement in margins over time?
First, I was just curious if you’re seeing any impact at all from the Apple iOS changes in your business and perhaps particularly in YouTube.

And then second, given retail, the biggest driver of services growth, and, of course, you’re really just touching all parts of the economy, any more commentary on how you’re thinking about supply and labor shortage dynamics in the fourth quarter and if you’re perhaps seeing anything thus far there?
Just to follow-up on YouTube. Can you maybe talk to the ecommerce opportunity that you’re seeing evolve? Where are you at now and eventually where you would like to be?

When you look at Search in the quarter, it really accelerated beyond the comp. And if you look at it quarter-over-quarter, it was really good. So wondering if there’s any products or verticals that really surprised you or things to call out.
And how do you think about the sustainability here, specifically in Search and the product pipeline from here?

And then, secondly, on Cloud, really saw a nice margin improvement there. How do you feel about where you are on the infrastructure side and ability to really continue to show kind of that improvement in margins over time?

First off looking at GCP and some of the innovations you’ve talked about like distributed cloud, I just wonder what you think the long-term future is for hybrid cloud environments. Are they really -- or is this just really a part of the process or stepping stones to bring more companies or most companies over to full cloud adoption?

And then, secondly, we’re seeing a clear blurring of the lines among eCommerce, digital payments and social platforms. So I was hoping you could share the vision for Google and YouTube and the other Google apps in this context, how those pieces fit together as a closed loop shopping platform, if that’s the right way to think about it.
Is there anything that suggests that some of these ATT headwinds for other people in the industry actually cause shifts in budget over to your platforms, your different platforms?

And then, Ruth, just on the margins, is there anything other than revenue overage, that really strong revenue performance, flowing against fixed costs and the extended depreciation schedules that’s causing those margins to rise? Or have you been able to, you know, work out, eke out, tweak out, new efficiencies in the model itself?

Just a minute ago Philipp spoke to the acceleration in streaming and smart TVs worldwide and the importance that YouTube has on the TV [indiscernible]. I wanted to hear from you about your interest in supporting the smart TV ecosystem, and what do you see as the opportunity for Google in terms of your product offerings to maybe improve consumer adoption of Connected TVs?

And then for you, Philipp, people have been asking you about Search. But if you look at Search from a two-year stack, the growth is as high as it’s been in years. And I wonder if you can disaggregate for us the growth between maybe new Search customers coming on the platform versus increased spending on an existing per-customer basis? Anything to help us on kind of what drove it on a client-by-client basis on Search.

If I take your ad dollars, this quarter $50 billion and annualize, it’s like $200 billion a year. Are you or the board focused at all on trying to diversify away from the ad market or do you just feel like there’s so much runway that there is no real reason to stay focused on non-ad-based growth?

Sundar, I think in the past we’ve talked about the intersection of hardware and software for Google. And, you know, you touched on the Pixel 6 as well as the other examples in your prepared remarks. But as you look at all the different directions you’re going with Fitbit, Nest, and all the other devices, how has your thinking evolved over the years? And what do you envision a hardware and software, you know, integrated Google meaning to the consumer over the longer term?

And I guess, Philipp, if you look at some of the emerging and developing markets today, you know, some of the companies there around the world have had to play multiple roles in helping to solve for transactional friction by rolling out payments, logistics and other solutions that we probably take for granted here in the States. So do you think Google should or could play a more expansive role in India and some of the other emerging markets to help accelerate the growth of eCommerce versus the role that, you know, you play in the U.S. and the West.

I just had a high-level question on YouTube. So you’re obviously doing really well there, and as large as it is and as high as the engagement is compared to just about any other app that we see across the broader Internet, the revenue at just around $30 billion this year pales in comparison to, you know, core Facebook or Instagram. So do you think that, you know, this is, obviously, a huge opportunity for YouTube, especially with Connected TV? Is there something that you guys need to change about your approach with either direct sales or kind of decoupling Search from YouTube and some of the other products that Google has under the same roof, or do you kind of think continuing along the same path is the right strategy for YouTube specifically? Any color on that would be helpful.

operating_environment_challenges: Impact of COVID-19 on advertising and consumer behavior
Adapting product offerings to shift towards digital and remote work
Managing risks in Other Bets such as Waymo and Verily
Capital allocation between growth investments and shareholder returns
Ensuring safety and content responsibility on platforms like YouTube
Competition in eCommerce and online retail
Leadership transitions within subsidiaries like Waymo
Supply chain and labor shortages impacting various sectors

new_leadership.name: Bill Ready
new_leadership.context: Recently appointed to lead commerce initiatives, focusing on commission-free models and enhancing eCommerce efforts.

successor.name: Dmitri and Tekedra
successor.context: Working closely with outgoing CEO to ensure smooth transition and continued investment in autonomous driving technologies.
